questions.text: A lady with history of smoking presents with nipple discharge. She is diagnosed with duct ectasia. What is the procedure to be done? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hadfield procedure

 

In this case, the patient has a history of smoking and presents with nipple discharge, leading to a diagnosis of duct ectasia. Duct ectasia typically affects multiple ducts rather than a single duct. The appropriate procedure for duct ectasia, where multiple ducts are involved, is the Hadfield procedure. This involves excising the affected ducts using a conical incision.

 

If the discharge was coming from a single duct and was bloody, the diagnosis could be ductal papilloma. The treatment for ductal papilloma is microdochectomy, which involves excising the single affected duct with the tumor inside it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microdochectomy: This is incorrect in the context of duct ectasia, as it is used for excising a single duct with a tumor, such as in ductal papilloma.

 

Option C. Simple mastectomy: This is incorrect because it involves removing the entire breast, which is not necessary for ductal disorders like duct ectasia.

 

Option D. Wide local excision: This is incorrect as it is not typically used for treating ductal disorders like duct ectasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hadfield procedure is used to excise multiple affected ducts in patients with duct ectasia.

questions.text: A patient recovered from Covid-19, treated with steroids, now presents with nasal discharge for 3 weeks. What does the histopathological image indicate? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucor

 

Explanation:

 

The histopathological image shows broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typical of Mucor species, suggesting a diagnosis of mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Typically shows septate hyphae with acute angle branching.

 

Option C. Candida: Forms yeast cells and pseudohyphae, not hyphae.

 

Option D. Trichosporon: Forms hyaline hyphae and arthroconidia, different from what is seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucor is the cause of fungal infections characterized by broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those recently treated with steroids post-Covid-19 infection.

questions.text: Which ganglia is affected due to the involvement of the nerve located at the marked area? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pterygopalatine ganglia

 

The marked area on the skull image points to a region near the pterygoid plates and the palatine bone, specifically associated with the pterygopalatine fossa. This fossa houses the pterygopalatine ganglion, which is responsible for relaying parasympathetic nerve fibers from the facial nerve to the lacrimal glands, nasal glands, and palatine glands.

 

The pterygopalatine ganglion is located within the pterygopalatine fossa, a small space beneath the apex of the orbit, posterior to the maxilla. The ganglion receives preganglionic parasympathetic fibers from the greater petrosal nerve, a branch of the facial nerve, and is involved in various autonomic functions related to the glands in the region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Submandibular ganglia: This ganglion is located below the mandible and is associated with the submandibular and sublingual glands. It is not related to the region marked in the image, which is closer to the pterygopalatine fossa.

 

Option B. Ciliary ganglia: The ciliary ganglion is located in the orbit and is associated with the eye, specifically controlling the ciliary muscle and the sphincter pupillae. It is not related to the marked area on the skull image.

 

Option D. Otic ganglia: The otic ganglion is associated with the parotid gland and is located just below the foramen ovale. While it plays a role in salivary secretion, it is not connected to the region indicated in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterygopalatine ganglion is located in the pterygopalatine fossa and is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of the lacrimal, nasal, and palatine glands. This ganglion is specifically affected by involvement in the region marked in the skull image.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cyclophosphamide

 

Explanation:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent used to treat various cancers and autoimmune diseases. One of its known side effects is the increased risk of developing bladder carcinoma. This is due to the metabolite acrolein, which can cause urothelial damage leading to malignancy. Long-term use or high doses of cyclophosphamide significantly elevate this risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cisplatin: Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug effective against various cancers, including testicular, ovarian, and bladder cancer. However, it is not specifically associated with the development of bladder carcinoma as a side effect.

 

Option C. Taxane (e.g., paclitaxel, docetaxel): Taxanes are chemotherapeutic agents used in treating breast, ovarian, and lung cancers. They are not linked to bladder carcinoma development.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is primarily used to treat breast cancer. While it can increase the risk of endometrial cancer due to its estrogen-like effects on uterine tissue, it is not associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Additional Information on Drugs Associated with Bladder Cancer: Several drugs have been associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer, including:

  • Pioglitazone: A drug used to treat type 2 diabetes.
  • Aristolochic acid: Found in some herbal remedies.
  • Phenacetin: An analgesic and antipyretic.
  • Aminosalicylates: Used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma due to its metabolite acrolein, which can damage the bladder lining.

questions.text: Increased firing of which of the following is responsible for the occurrence of scissoring gait? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obturator nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Scissoring gait is characterized by the crossing of the legs while walking, which resembles the closing of a pair of scissors. This gait abnormality is primarily due to increased tone and overactivity of the adductor muscles of the thighs, which are responsible for bringing the legs together.

 

The adductor muscles are innervated by the obturator nerve. Increased firing or hyperactivity of the obturator nerve leads to excessive contraction of the adductor muscles, resulting in the scissoring motion seen in this gait disorder.

 

Treatment options for scissoring gait may include interventions such as obturator nerve cryoneurolysis, where the obturator nerve is intentionally damaged to reduce muscle spasticity and improve gait.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: This nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the thigh, including the quadriceps muscles, which are involved in knee extension, not adduction.

 

Option B. Superior gluteal nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles, which are involved in hip abduction and stabilization, not adduction.

 

Option C. Inferior gluteal nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus maximus muscle, which is primarily responsible for hip extension and lateral rotation, not adduction.

 

Educational Objectives

 

Scissoring gait is caused by increased firing of the obturator nerve, leading to overactivity of the adductor muscles of the thighs.

questions.text: A 6-months-old child presented with cyanosis and fatigue. His chest X ray is shown below. What is the most likely sign and diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Snowman sign, Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Explanation:

 

The given X-ray shows a case of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC) with figure of 8 or snowman or cottage-loaf appearance.

 

TAPVC:

 

  • TAPVC is a condition in which pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium. As a result, pulmonary venous blood flow drains abnormally into the systemic venous circulation.
  • It is a cyanotic heart disease with congestive heart failure symptoms. The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.

 

The following types are seen:

 

I. Supra cardiac – Most common type

II. Cardiac

III. Infra cardiac – Most common type for obstruction (worst prognosis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cottage loaf, truncus arteriosus: Truncus arteriosus involves a single arterial trunk coming from the heart, not typically showing a snowman sign.

 

Option C. Egg on side, TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): This condition typically shows an "egg on a string" appearance due to the abnormal positioning of the great arteries.

 

Option D. Boot shaped heart, TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): Characterized by a boot-shaped heart on X-ray due to right ventricular hypertrophy; not the pattern observed in this image.'

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "snowman sign" on a chest X-ray in a child presenting with cyanosis and fatigue is highly suggestive of Supracardiac TAPVC.

choices.text: BCR ABL

questions.text: All-trans retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumor that is associated with which of the following genetic aberrations? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PML-RARA

 

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML), which is associated with the PML-RARA fusion gene.

 

The long arm of chromosome 17 encodes the retinoic acid alpha receptor gene (RARA). It is primarily expressed in hematopoietic cells and plays an important role in gene expression regulation. RARA is bound by the nuclear corepressor factor in the absence of retinoid acid, causing transcriptional repression. RARA is activated in the presence of retinoic acid, and promyelocytes undergo terminal differentiation.

 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is a distinct subtype of acute leukemia distinguished by abnormal promyelocyte proliferation, life-threatening coagulopathy, and the chromosome translocation t (15;17) (q22;q11-12). This results in an abnormal fusion protein known as PML-RARA, which has a low affinity for retinoids. This inhibits transcription and thus prevents gene expression for cellular differentiation. This leads to the accumulation of myeloid progenitor cells.

 

 

Rx: The condition is treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA). It binds to the PML-RARA chimeric protein. This causes conformational change such that the protein regains its normal function and activates DNA transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BCR-ABL: Associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

 

  • Treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib, not ATRA.

 

Option C. CMYC: Associated with Burkitt lymphoma.

 

  • Involves translocation t (8;14) affecting the c-Myc oncogene.

 

Option D. RUNX1-ETO: Associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with t (8;21).

 

  • Treated with standard chemotherapy regimens, not specifically ATRA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion gene resulting from the t(15;17) translocation. This treatment promotes the differentiation of leukemic promyelocytes, improving clinical outcomes in APL patients.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice has a distended gall bladder and a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound. Which of the following will be most useful to localize the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

 

Given scenario of an elderly male with obstructive jaundice and distended gall bladder, is suggestive of periampullary tumour. The best investigation would be a CECT abdomen (not provided in the option) or MRCP.

 

Correct. MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique that visualizes the biliary and pancreatic ducts. It provides detailed images without the need for ionizing radiation or invasive procedures. Given the patient's age and presentation, MRCP is an ideal choice to visualize obstructions or abnormalities in the bile duct system without posing additional risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This is a useful modality for visualizing the biliary tree, pancreas, and surrounding structures. It can be particularly helpful in assessing small lesions or stones that might be missed by other imaging modalities. It would be utilised if MRCP/CECT did not yield adequate diagnosis, or for staging of periampullary tumors.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography: This is an invasive procedure where contrast is injected directly into the biliary system through the liver, and then X-rays are taken. It can be diagnostic as well as therapeutic (e.g., for bile duct drainage). However, it's more invasive than MRCP and might not be the first choice for solely diagnostic purposes in a 72-year-old patient.

 

Option D. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It involves inserting an endoscope through the mouth to the duodenum and injecting contrast into the bile and pancreatic ducts. While ERCP can visualize and treat obstructions, it's invasive and carries risks like pancreatitis, especially if used primarily for diagnostic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obstructive jaundice is a condition in which there is a blockage of the flow of bile out of the liver. This results in redirection of excess bile and its by-products into the blood, and bile excretion from the body is incomplete

 

Symptoms of obstructive jaundice include yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes; paler stools and darker urine; and intense itching.

 

The most common cause of obstructive jaundice is the presence of CBD stones (choledocholithiasis). Other causes of obstructive jaundice are tumors, trauma, cysts, and inflammation in the bile ducts.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ligament of Treitz

 

The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It is a part of the duodenojejunal junction.

 

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower Gl bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ampulla of Vater: The ampulla of Vater is the point where the pancreatic duct and common bile duct converge and enter the second part of the duodenum. It is an essential structure for the drainage of both bile and pancreatic enzymes into the duodenum. It is not used as a demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Option C. Superior duodenal flexure: The superior duodenal flexure is the bend in the duodenum as it transitions from the first part (horizontal) to the second part (descending).

 

Option D. Ileocecal junction: The ileocecal junction is the point where the ileum meets the cecum. The ileocecal valve is present here, preventing the reflux of colonic contents into the ileum. While it's an important anatomical landmark in the gastrointestinal tract, it's not used as the demarcation point for differentiating between upper and lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ligament of Treitz is the anatomical demarcation point used to differentiate upper gastrointestinal bleeding (proximal to the ligament) from lower gastrointestinal bleeding (distal to the ligament).

choices.text: It can be reduced by matching
It is associated individually with both cause and effect
It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding a confounding factor? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) It is distributed equally in both study and control groups

 

  • Confounding factor: Any factor associated with both exposure and outcome, and has an independent effect in causation of outcome is a confounder.
  • It is found unequally distributed between the study and control groups

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can be reduced by matching:  Matching is a technique used in study design to control for confounding by ensuring that study groups are comparable with respect to potential confounders.

 

Option C. It is distributed equally in both study and control groups:  This statement is incorrect. A confounding factor is typically unequally distributed between the study and control groups. If it were equally distributed, it would not confound the results.

 

Option D. It is associated with the exposure of the study:  A confounder is associated with the exposure and can influence the observed effect of the exposure on the outcome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Confounding can be removed by

 

1. Matching → MC used /simplest method

2. Randomization → 2nd Best Method

3. Restriction

4. Stratification

5. Statistical Modelling / Multivariate analysis (MVA)

6. Stratified Randomization → Overall Best Method

questions.text: Match the following molecules with their carriers in plasma: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a

 

1-b . Transthyretin (TTR) or Prealbumin is a tetrameric transport protein highly conserved through vertebrate evolution and synthesized in the liver, choroid plexus, and retinal pigment epithelium. TTR transports the thyroid hormone thyroxine and the retinol-binding protein (RBP) bound to retinol (vitamin A).

 

 2-c. Transcobalamins are carrier proteins which bind cobalamin (B12). Transcobalamin I (TCN1), also known as haptocorrin, R-factor, and R-protein, is a glycoprotein produced by the salivary glands of the mouth. It primarily serves to protect cobalamin (Vitamin B12) from acid degradation in the stomach by producing a Haptocorrin-Vitamin B12 complex. Once the complex has traveled to the more neutral duodenum, pancreatic proteases degrade haptocorrin, releasing free cobalamin, which now binds to intrinsic factor for absorption by ileal enterocytes. Transcobalamin II (TCN2) binds cobalamin once it has been taken up by enterocytes of the terminal ileum and the "Intrinsic Factor-Vitamin B12" complex has been degraded. Transcobalamin II is then involved with the transport of Vitamin B12 to the tissues.

 

 3-d. Haptoglobin (abbreviated as Hp) in blood plasma, haptoglobin binds with high affinity to free hemoglobin released from erythrocytes, and thereby inhibits its deleterious oxidative activity. 

 

4-a. Hemopexin binds to free heme. The haptoglobin-hemoglobin complex will then be removed by the reticuloendothelial system (mostly the spleen).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct pairs are as follows:

 

1. Thyroxine - b. Pre-albumin

2. Vitamin B12 - c. Transcobalamin

3. Hemoglobin - d. Haptoglobin

4. Heme - a. Hemopexin

questions.text: Ebola virus comes under which Biosafety level category as given by WHO? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4.

 

Ebola virus requires the highest level of containment, BSL-4, due to its extreme pathogenicity and the severe risk it poses to both laboratory personnel and the community.

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) classifies infectious agents into four Biosafety Levels (BSLs), based on their potential to cause disease and the precautions required to handle them safely:

 

  • Biosafety Level 1 (BSL-1): This is for work with low-risk microbes that pose minimal threat to laboratory workers and the environment, such as non-pathogenic strains of E. coli, non-pathogenic staphylococcus, Saccharomyces cerevisiae (a type of yeast) and Bacillus subtilis.
  • Biosafety Level 2 (BSL-2): This level is appropriate for work involving agents that pose moderate hazards to personnel and the environment. This includes pathogens like Pathogenic E coli, pathogenic Staphylococcus aureus, hepatitis viruses A B & C, HIV, toxoplasma, malaria (plasmodium falciparum) and salmonella.
  • Biosafety Level 3 (BSL-3): This level is used for agents that can cause serious or potentially lethal diseases through inhalation, such as rickettsial diseases, Q fever, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Psittacosis, brucella, yellow fever virus, Yersinia pestis, EEEV and corona virus (SARS-CoV-2).
  • Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4): This is the highest level of biosafety and is used for handling agents that pose a high risk of life-threatening disease for which there are no vaccines or treatments. The Ebola virus, Marburg virus, Lassa virus, Nipah virus, flavivirus, and Lassa virus, falls under this category due to its high fatality rate and the absence of effective treatments.

 

Note - For COVID-19 both biosafety level 2 and 3 are correct; 2 is for routine testing & diagnostic testing, and 3 is for culture and virus isolation

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ebola virus is classified under Biosafety Level 4 (BSL-4) by WHO, indicating it is one of the most dangerous pathogens requiring the highest level of containment.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaint of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homogentisate oxidase

 

Option A. Homogentisate oxidase: This is the correct enzyme.

 

Alkaptonuria is caused by a deficiency of homogentisate oxidase, which leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in the body. This acid can darken upon exposure to air, resulting in blackened urine and other symptoms.

 

It is compatible with fairly normal life. The only abnormality is the blackening of urine on standing. The homogentisic acid is oxidized by polyphenol oxidase to benzoquinone acetate. It is then polymerized to black colored alkaptone bodies.

 

By the 3rd or 4th decade of life, patient may develop ochronosis (deposition of alkaptone bodies in intervertebral discs, cartilages of nose, pinna of ear). Black pigments are deposited over the connective tissues including joint cavities to produce arthritis.

 

Diagnosis of Alkaptonuria:

 

  1. Urine becomes black on standing when it becomes alkaline. Blackening is accelerated on exposure to sunlight and oxygen. The urine when kept in a test tube will start to blacken from the top layer.
  2. Ferric chloride test will be positive for urine.
  3. Benedict’s test is strongly positive. Due to reducing nature of homogentisic acid in urine.

 

Treatment: No specific treatment is required. But minimal protein intake with phenylalanine less than 500 mg/day is recommended.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Xanthine oxidase: Xanthine oxidase is not associated with Alkaptonuria. It is involved in the metabolism of purines, not in the pathway related to this condition.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU), a different metabolic disorder causing mousy/musty body odor.

 

Option D. Dihydro orotate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of the pyrimidine biosynthesis pathway and is not related to Alkaptonuria.

 

Educational objective:

 

The diagnosis is alkaptonuria in which urine becomes black on standing due to oxidation of homogentisic acid present in the urine. The disease is autosomal recessive inherited and it is due to the deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase/dioxygenase required for further metabolism of homogentisic acid.

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased sensation in the lateral 3 ½ fingers of the palmar side of the right hand along with difficulty moving the upper phalanx of the thumb. Associated thenar atrophy is also present. What is the associated nerve injury in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High median nerve

 

The symptoms described in the question indicate involvement of the median nerve, particularly the high median nerve. The high median nerve innervates the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, controls thumb movement, and supplies the thenar muscles responsible for thumb functions. Injury to this nerve can lead to sensory loss and motor deficits, such as difficulty moving the thumb and thenar atrophy, as mentioned in the question. The presence of sensory loss, along with thenar atrophy, strongly indicates a high median nerve injury, rather than its branches like the anterior interosseous nerve, which does not affect sensory perception.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily supplies the medial side of the hand, including the little finger and half of the ring finger. It does not innervate the lateral 3 ½ fingers or the thenar muscles. Therefore, an injury to the ulnar nerve would not present with the described sensory and motor deficits.

 

Option B. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm and provides sensation to the dorsal aspect of the hand. It does not supply the thenar muscles or the palmar side of the fingers described in the question. Hence, it cannot be the correct answer.

 

Option C. Anterior interosseous nerve: This nerve is a deep branch of the median nerve, which primarily supplies deep muscles in the forearm like the flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and part of the flexor digitorum profundus. It does not carry sensory fibers, so it would not cause sensory loss or thenar atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high median nerve injury is characterized by sensory loss in the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, difficulty moving the thumb, and associated thenar atrophy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome presents with symptoms suggestive of a gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence in MEN 1 syndrome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Duodenum

 

Explanation:

 

In patients with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN 1 and are often found in the first and second parts of the duodenum.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview:

 

  • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors.
  • The main features of MEN 1 include:
    • Parathyroid tumors: These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1.
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs): These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas.
    • Pituitary tumors: These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).

 

Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome:

 

  • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Gastrinomas are less commonly found in the jejunum compared to the duodenum in MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option B. Ileum: The ileum is not a common site for gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome. The duodenum is the primary site.

 

Option D. Stomach: While gastrinomas can theoretically occur in the stomach, they are most commonly found in the duodenum in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MEN 1 syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. They are the most frequent functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with this genetic disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked green in the image below? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opponens pollicis

 

Explanation:

 

The palmar aspect of the first metacarpal is the area marked in the image. At this location, the opponens pollicis muscle inserts.

 

  • Opponens pollicis:
  • Origin: Crest of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

 

The image below shows various intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor Pollicis Longus: Abductor pollicis longus is not directly attached to the first metacarpal. It originates from the posterior surface of the ulna and radius and inserts into the base of the first metacarpal bone. Its primary action is to abduct the thumb away from the palm.

 

Option B. Palmar Interossei: The palmar interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones in the palm of the hand. They are responsible for adducting the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They are not directly attached to the first metacarpal.

 

Option D. Flexor Pollicis Brevis: The flexor pollicis brevis muscle has two heads: the superficial head and the deep head. The superficial head originates from the flexor retinaculum, while the deep head originates from the trapezoid and capitate bones.

  • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone.
  • The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the Crest of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone.
  • The primary action of the opponens pollicis is to oppose the thumb, allowing for the grasping and pinching movements of the thumb.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Periampullary carcinoma

 

The most probable diagnosis in this patient is periampullary carcinoma.

 

Here are the characteristic features of periampullary carcinoma:

 

  • Arises from the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater
  • Presents with jaundice that intermittently waxes and wanes due to partial relief of obstruction to bile ducts whenever the tumor undergoes necrosis and sloughing
  • Other symptoms include weight loss, pain, nausea, vomiting, pruritus, fever, and gastrointestinal bleeding
  • A three-phase CT scan is recommended for diagnosis- which shows double duct sign (dilated CBD and pancreatic duct).
  • Management includes resection, along with chemotherapy/chemoradiotherapy

 

Periampullary carcinoma refers to cancers that arise in the vicinity of the ampulla of Vater, where the bile duct and pancreatic duct converge before entering the duodenum. These tumors can obstruct both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct, leading to intermittent or waxing and waning jaundice. The anatomical location of periampullary carcinomas and double duct sign on CT makes them a likely cause in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholangiocarcinoma: Cholangiocarcinoma is a cancer that originates in the bile ducts. While it can cause obstructive jaundice, it typically presents with a more gradual and progressive course of symptoms. It may cause dilatation of the bile ducts, but waxing and waning jaundice is less characteristic of cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Common bile duct stone: While a common bile duct stone can cause obstructive jaundice, it typically leads to a more acute presentation with sudden onset of symptoms. Waxing and waning jaundice is not a common feature of common bile duct stones.

 

Option D. Head of pancreas carcinoma: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas, also known as pancreatic head carcinoma, can obstruct the common bile duct and cause jaundice. However, it tends to present with a more persistent and progressive form of jaundice rather than waxing and waning symptoms, as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periampullary carcinoma (option B) is the most likely cause of waxing and waning jaundice in an alcoholic patient with dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct on CT examination due to its anatomical location and its potential to obstruct both ducts.

questions.text:
Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following options: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

 

Non-scarring alopecia is characterized by hair loss without destruction of the hair follicle, allowing for the potential regrowth of hair. The options provided include three conditions that typically result in non-scarring alopecia:

 

1. Alopecia areata: An autoimmune disorder that causes patchy hair loss on the scalp and other parts of the body. This condition is non-scarring, as the hair follicles are not destroyed and hair can regrow if the underlying autoimmune process is controlled or subsides.

 

2. Telogen effluvium: A condition characterized by widespread thinning of the hair, often triggered by a significant stress event, illness, or hormonal change. It results from a large number of hair follicles entering the resting phase (telogen) simultaneously. Recovery is possible once the triggering event is resolved, and the follicles remain intact.

 

3. Androgenic alopecia: Commonly known as male or female pattern baldness, this is a genetic condition influenced by androgens (hormones). It involves hair thinning in a characteristic pattern and is non-scarring, as the hair follicles gradually produce thinner, shorter hairs but are not completely destroyed.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a form of scarring alopecia. It involves a progressive, symmetrical band of hair loss at the front of the scalp along with loss of eyebrows. The scarring means that the hair follicles are permanently destroyed, preventing the regrowth of hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional Information

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD presented with acute exacerbation and in type 2 respiratory failure was admitted to the ICU. Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the initial management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Non-Invasive PPV should be given

 

Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV) is often the initial treatment of choice for patients with COPD who present with an acute exacerbation and are in type 2 respiratory failure (characterized by hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis). NIPPV can improve gas exchange and reduce the work of breathing without the need for endotracheal intubation, thereby decreasing the risk of infection and other complications associated with invasive mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (IPPV): This is generally reserved for patients who fail NIPPV or present with severe acidosis, hemodynamic instability, or decreased level of consciousness that precludes the use of NIPPV.

 

Option C. IV corticosteroids: While systemic corticosteroids are commonly used in the management of acute COPD exacerbations, the initial focus in a patient in respiratory failure should be on stabilizing the patient's breathing and gas exchange. Corticosteroids can be administered orally or intravenously, but this would not be the primary concern in the immediate management.

 

Note - Oral steroids (prednisolone) is given for 5-14 days in acute exacerbations.

 

Option D. Permissive hypercapnia: This is a strategy used in mechanical ventilation where slightly elevated levels of carbon dioxide (hypercapnia) are tolerated to avoid high ventilatory pressures that can lead to lung injury, however pH is maintained above 7.3. It is applicable during mechanical ventilation if it becomes necessary but is not an initial management step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a COPD patient presenting with acute exacerbation and respiratory failure, non-invasive ventilation is the preferred initial management strategy to stabilize the patient's respiratory status, reducing the need for intubation and potentially improving clinical outcomes.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/COPD/chapter 292

questions.text: What is the reason behind Senile Atrophy? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced blood supply

 

Senile atrophy is seen when there is a reduced blood supply to a tissue.

 

  • Atrophy is decrease in cell size and/or number due to decreased demand or functional loss.
  • 2 pathways responsible for it: Ubiquitin Pathway (via Proteasomes) and Autophagy (Defense mechanism).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Denervation: Atrophy due to loss of nerve supply is known as denervation atrophy, commonly seen in conditions like poliomyelitis.

 

Option B. Decreased nutrition: This refers to atrophy due to inadequate nutrient supply, leading to cachexia.

 

Option C. Decreased workload: This refers to disuse atrophy, where tissues reduce in size due to inactivity, such as muscle wasting in immobilized limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Senile atrophy is primarily due to reduced blood supply, leading to tissue shrinkage and loss of function with aging.

choices.text: Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities

questions.text: Which of the following findings are seen in a high-resolution CT scan of fungal pneumonia?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities 

 

Explanation:

 

Invasive aspergillosis

 

  1. HALO SIGN – Multiple nodules with central solid part and haziness around the lesion
  2. Seen in immunocompromised individuals with febrile neutropenia
  3. DOC – voriconazole

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kerley lines: Commonly associated with interstitial edema and pulmonary congestion, not specifically fungal pneumonia.

 

Option B. Hilar lymph nodes: While enlargement can be seen in various conditions, it is not a specific finding for fungal pneumonia.

 

Option C. Pleural effusion: Although it may be present in various lung infections and conditions, it is not characteristic of fungal infections like invasive aspergillosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavitatory lesions with surrounding ground glass opacities on a high-resolution CT scan are indicative of fungal infections like invasive aspergillosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. Recognition of these signs is crucial for the timely initiation of appropriate antifungal therapy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with eclampsia is on a maintenance dose of MgSO₄. When will you stop MgSO₄? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine output 60ml in 4hr


Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) is used in eclampsia management to prevent seizures. However, MgSO₄ toxicity can occur, which necessitates stopping or adjusting the dose. The first sign of MgSO₄ toxicity is the absence of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs), followed by respiratory depression and reduced urine output. Since magnesium is excreted through the kidneys, urine output is a critical measure of magnesium toxicity risk. A urine output of less than 30 ml per hour (or 60 ml in 4 hours) indicates poor excretion and potential toxicity, requiring immediate adjustment or cessation of MgSO₄.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knee jerk present: The presence of a knee jerk (deep tendon reflex) is a positive sign and indicates that magnesium levels are not yet toxic. The absence of DTRs is the first indication of toxicity, so this is not a reason to stop MgSO₄.

 

Option B. RR 18/min: A respiratory rate above 10 breaths per minute is safe when on MgSO₄. Respiratory depression is a sign of advanced toxicity; therefore, a rate of 18 per minute is not concerning.

 

Option C. Visual disturbances: Visual disturbances are symptoms associated with eclampsia or pre-eclampsia (e.g., retinal detachment or blurred vision) but are not signs of MgSO₄ toxicity. These do not indicate the need to stop MgSO₄.

 

Educational Objective:


MgSO₄ should be stopped if the patient’s urine output is less than 30 ml per hour (or 60 ml in 4 hours), as this indicates poor excretion and risk of magnesium toxicity.

questions.text: Identify the sign and the tendon ruptured in the image given below: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proximal biceps tendon rupture

 

PROXIMAL BICEPS TENDON RUPTURE

 

  • The biceps brachii muscle has two heads, one originating from the coracoid process (short head) and the other from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula and superior labrum (long head).
  • The distal biceps tendon attaches to the bicipital tuberosity of the radius.
  • The biceps tendon is a strong supinator of the forearm and serves as a weak elbow flexor.
  • The long head (proximal biceps tendon) contributes to the stability of the glenohumeral joint. The majority of biceps rupture involves the long head.
  • Etiology:
    • Proximal biceps rupture is generally not due to a unique mechanism of injury but is highly correlated with rotator cuff disease.
    • Risk factors include age, smoking, obesity, use of corticosteroids, and overuse.
    • Rare causes include the use of quinolones, diabetes, lupus, and chronic kidney disease.
       
  • Epidemiology:
    • Proximal biceps rupture is commonly seen in older patients, and its exact incidence is unknown, but it is more common than distal biceps rupture in older patients.
       
  • Pathophysiology
    • The proximal tendon rupture, in most cases, occurs at the tendon-labral junction or the bony attachment.
       
  • Clinical features:
    • Patients may complain of sudden sharp pain in the elbow or shoulder, depending on the site of the rupture.
    • Usually, there is a history of sudden eccentric force to a flexed elbow. They may feel an audible "pop" in the affected arm at the time of the injury.
    • Pain can persist for weeks to months.
    • Pain may diminish if the tendon is completely torn.
    • Patients usually complain of bulbous mass in the upper arm due to excessive retraction of the biceps muscle belly, known as "Popeye deformity." In obese individuals, it is generally hard to appreciate this popeye deformity.

 

  • Proximal biceps rupture does not result in any long-term change in the elbow or shoulder strength.
  • It is important to check for atrophy of the shoulder girdle muscle and shoulder impingement because proximal biceps tendon disorders are usually associated with rotator cuff pathology.
     
  • Evaluation:
    • Diagnosis is often clinically made, while imaging is helpful when the diagnosis is unclear or partial rupture is considered.
    • Three criteria are described for diagnosis:
      1. History of a single traumatic event. The patient will report a sudden, painful pop while the elbow is eccentrically loaded from flexion to extension. e.g., while doing a biceps curl.
      2. Grossly palpable and visible signs of retraction of the biceps muscle belly (reverse popeye deformity).
      3. Weakness of elbow flexion and supination of the forearm in cases of distal biceps rupture.
         
  • Treatment:
    • Non-surgical treatment is usually sufficient for proximal tendon rupture, as it is more common in elderly patients. However, residual cosmetic deformity and some intermittent biceps muscle cramping may persist.
    • Younger patients and female patients who are unwilling to accept cosmetic deformities and athletic patients with frequent cramping may opt for surgical intervention in the form of biceps tenodesis.
    • The presence of associated rotator cuff pathology can also influence surgical management.
    • Subpectoral tenodesis is the preferred approach for biceps tenodesis, where the tendon is attached to the bone in the bicipital groove. Sometimes this procedure is done concurrently with arthroscopic rotator cuff pathology treatment. Implants like interference screws and bio-absorbable suture anchors can be placed either through the open or arthroscopic approach to secure the tendon in the subpectoral space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Distal biceps tendon rupture. The distal biceps tendon inserts onto the ulnar aspect of the bicipital tuberosity (also called radial tuberosity). The likely pathophysiological mechanism predisposing the distal biceps to rupture is a compromised zone of hypovascularity due to watershed zone of arterial blood supply and reduced distance between the upper parts of radius and the ulna during pronation. An aching sensation in the anterior elbow is seen in 10% of the patients. Majority of the patients with a full thickness distal biceps rupture reports a painful “pop” sensation. Anterior elbow pain, anterior arm and elbow swelling and weakness of elbow flexion and forearm supination are commonly reported symptoms. Activities such as operating a manual screw driver or opening jars are difficult to perform by involved arm. In a torn distal biceps, there would be anterior ecchymosis, swelling and a prominent biceps bulge at the anterior mid-arm level (Popeye the sailor sign).

 

 

Option C. Triceps tendon rupture. Triceps Ruptures are rare injuries to the elbow extensor mechanism that most commonly occurs as a result of a sudden forceful elbow contraction in weightlifters or older males with underlying systemic illness. Patients tend to be men who practice sports and are from 30 to 50 years of age. The triceps lesions are characterised by pain or tenderness and a palpable defect in the tendon, seen proximal to the olecranon. The patient describes an unexpected “pop” or giving way, with subsequent pain and weakness in the extremity. A complete triceps rupture can be expected when the patient is unable to extend his arm against gravity. A palpable defect is not always present, but sometimes can be found in the posterior arm. Swelling and echymosis are other nonspecific findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The deformity shown in the given image in the question is seen in proximal biceps tendon rupture and is called Popeye deformity.

questions.text: Deamination of methylated cytosine will form: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thymine

 

  • Deamination of methylated cytosine results in the conversion of cytosine to thymine. This process is important in DNA repair mechanisms and helps maintain the integrity of the genetic code. Thymine is one of the four standard nucleobases in DNA and pairs with adenine in DNA base pairing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uracil: Uracil is not formed from the deamination of methylated cytosine. Uracil is one of the four standard nucleobases in RNA and is not a product of cytosine deamination.

 

Option B. Guanine: Guanine is another nucleobase and is not produced by the deamination of methylated cytosine.

 

Option C. Adenine: Adenine is one of the four standard nucleobases in DNA and RNA and is not the product of cytosine deamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymine is a pyrimidine. The structure of different pyrimidines can be shown as:

 

 

Now, it is clear from the figure below that if methylated cytosine is deaminated it will form thymine as:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 323

choices.text: It is detected in blood during sepsis
It is produced in response to bacterial infection.
It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding neutrophil extracellular trapping (NET)? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial DNA is seen

 

Mitochondrial DNA is not seen in neutrophil extracellular traps (NET). In classic NETosis, the DNA is nuclear, not mitochondrial.

 

Some rare reports suggest that under certain non-lytic forms, mitochondrial DNA may be extruded, but this is not typical of NETs as understood in bacterial infections or sepsis.

 

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are a network of neutrophil nuclear chromatin/DNA. The death of neutrophils is caused by the loss of nuclei. They assemble antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to combat bacteria and fungi (not viruses). During sepsis, they are detected in the blood.

 

They are produced by neutrophils in response to:

 

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is detected in blood during sepsis:

 

  • True Statement: NETs are indeed detected in the blood during sepsis as part of the body's response to widespread infection.

 

Option B. It is produced in response to bacterial infection:

 

  • True Statement: NETs are produced in response to bacterial infection as well as fungal infections.

 

Option D. It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes:

 

  • True Statement: NETs consist of chromatin (DNA) along with antibacterial enzymes and peptides, which help in trapping and killing pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are networks of nuclear DNA from neutrophils combined with antimicrobial enzymes and peptides, produced in response to bacterial and fungal infections. They play a crucial role in trapping and neutralizing pathogens. The presence of mitochondrial DNA in NETs is incorrect, as NETs are composed of nuclear chromatin.

questions.text: A young girl presented with a history of multiple episodes of loss of consciousness that lasted for 5-10 minutes. These episodes occur only in front of family members and only in the daytime. The patient can recall the conversation that happened around her during these episodes; there is no history of tongue bite and no incontinence. What is the preferred treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Treat with behavioral therapy

  

The patient's symptoms—episodes of apparent loss of consciousness only occurring in front of family members, during the day, with the ability to recall surrounding conversations—suggest that these are not true seizures but pseudoseizures, which are commonly associated with conversion disorder.

 

Conversion disorder is characterized by neurological symptoms without a medical or neurological cause, often triggered by psychological factors.

 

Behavioral therapy is the preferred treatment for conversion disorder. This approach helps the patient address and modify the underlying psychological factors contributing to their symptoms through techniques such as cognitive restructuring, relaxation techniques, and coping strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treat with aversive therapy: Aversive therapy involves applying unpleasant stimuli to reduce the occurrence of undesirable behaviors. It is considered unethical, especially in treating psychological disorders like conversion disorder, because it can cause harm and does not address the underlying psychological issues.

 

Option C. Valproate: Valproate is an antiepileptic medication used to treat true seizures, but it is not appropriate for conversion disorder or pseudoseizures since the condition is psychological rather than neurological.

 

Option D.  Ketogenic diet: The ketogenic diet is sometimes used to manage epilepsy but is not suitable for conversion disorder. The diet has no role in addressing psychological origins of symptoms like pseudoseizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred treatment for conversion disorder, which manifests with pseudoseizures, is behavioral therapy, not antiepileptic drugs or other seizure management strategies.

questions.text: Not included in STEPS approach for Non-communicable diseases is (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blood grouping

 

Explanation:

 

The WHO STEPS approach for non-communicable disease (NCD) risk factor & STROKE surveillance involves three steps: behavioral measurements, physical measurements, and biochemical measurements. These steps focus on key indicators related to NCDs and stroke surveillance.

 

The specific indicators include:

 

  • Step 1: Behavioral measurements – (for both core & expanded indicators) Tobacco use, alcohol consumption, diet, exercise, history of raised blood pressure, and diabetes mellitus.
  • Step 2: Physical measurements - Core indicators include height, weight, waist circumference, and blood pressure; expanded indicators include hip circumference and heart rate.
  • Step 3: Biochemical measurements - Core indicators include blood glucose and blood lipids; expanded indicators include triglycerides and serum cholesterol levels.

 

Blood grouping is not a part of the STEPS approach as it does not relate to the risk factors or measurements for NCDs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood sugar: Included as a core biochemical measurement (blood glucose).

 

Option B. Blood pressure: Included as a core physical measurement.

 

Option D. Blood lipids: Included as a core biochemical measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO STEPS approach for NCD risk factor surveillance includes behavioral, physical, and biochemical measurements, but blood grouping is not included in these indicators.

questions.text: A 30-year-man presents with swelling over knee joint. Biopsy reveals mononuclear and giant cells. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoclastoma

 

  • Lesion with giant cells and mononuclear cells in skeletally mature patient, GCT is the best answer.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as “Punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mononuclear giant cells in the histological findings is diagnostic for osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor.

questions.text: A 60-year-old farmer reports symptoms of fever, body pain, and a cough. A physical examination reveals a black lesion as depicted in the accompanying image. Laboratory tests confirm the presence of IgM antibodies indicative of Scrub Typhus infection. What treatment approach would be most advisable in this case? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Doxycycline alone

 

Explanation:

 

  • This black lesion is Eschar and this is the acute case of Scrub Typhus.
  • Causative organism - Rickettsia tsutsugamushi; Vector - Mite
  • The preferred approach depends on the severity of the condition and individual patient considerations.

 

Option A. Doxycycline Alone:

 

  1. Use: This is the first-line treatment for Scrub Typhus.
  2. Mechanism: Doxycycline works by inhibiting protein synthesis in bacteria, effectively controlling the infection.
  3. Why Prefer: It's highly effective and typically well-tolerated, making it suitable for most cases unless contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Doxycycline + Azithromycin: Used when there is co-infection with other pathogens that azithromycin can cover or when doxycycline alone isn't adequately effective.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone + Doxycycline: This combination might be used in more severe cases or when the patient has complications that might benefit from a broader antibiotic coverage.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone Alone: While effective against many types of bacteria, it's not the targeted treatment for Scrub Typhus and generally not recommended unless other options are contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Doxycycline alone is usually sufficient and most advisable for uncomplicated Scrub Typhus. 
  • Combination therapies may be considered in specific clinical scenarios where co-infections or severe presentations are evident.

choices.text: Valine substituted by glutamate at 6th position
Valine substituted by glutamate at 5th position
Glutamate substituted by valine at 5th position
Glutamate substituted by valine at 6th position

questions.text: A patient was in excruciating pain all over the body and went to hospital. This pain occurs after exercise. Patient has anemia with elongated RBCs. Sickle cell anemia diagnosis was made. Which of the following is true about this disease?(FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glutamate substituted by valine at 6th position

 

Explanation:

 

  • SCA is due to point mutation in the 6th codon of beta globin that leads to the replacement of a Glutamate (Polar) residue with a Valine (Nonpolar) residue
  • This substitution significantly alters the hemoglobin's physical properties, leading to the polymerization of hemoglobin under low oxygen conditions and causing the red blood cells to assume a sickle shape. These sickled cells lead to vascular occlusions and a range of complications including severe pain crises, often triggered by conditions such as strenuous exercise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnosis of SCA can be done by:

 

  • Hb electrophoresis—HbS migrate slower in an electric field because of less negative charge, because glutamate is replaced by valine
  • Sickling Test
  • HPLC to fractionate Hb
  • Isoelectric Focusing
  • Direct diagnosis by RFLP.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 657

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the central line insertion below the marked bone? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arterial puncture

 

Explanation:

 

The bone indicated in the image above is the left clavicle. An arterial puncture is the most common complication of a central line insertion below this bone.

 

  • Complications of central vein catheterization are - 
    • Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication.
    • Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
    • Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization.
    • Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
    • Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
    • Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins.
    • Infections

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Thrombophlebitis: Thrombophlebitis refers to inflammation of a vein associated with clot formation. While thrombophlebitis can occur following any central line placement, it's more commonly associated with peripheral IV lines. However, central venous catheters are more commonly associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is the formation of a blood clot inside the larger, deeper veins.

 

Option C. Empyema: Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity. While empyema itself is not a direct complication of central line placement, pneumothorax or hemothorax (air or blood in the pleural space, respectively) caused by central line placement can lead to infection and subsequently empyema if not recognized and treated.

 

Option D. Chylothorax: Chylothorax is the accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the pleural space. This can happen if the thoracic duct is damaged. The thoracic duct is a major lymphatic vessel that runs in the thorax but is not typically at risk with subclavian line placement. Chylothorax would be more of a concern with procedures that are done in close proximity to the thoracic duct, like surgeries or interventions in the mediastinum or around the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arterial puncture is one of the most common complications associated with the subclavian approach for central venous catheter placement. The subclavian artery lies directly beneath the vein, so inadvertent puncture of the artery can occur if the needle is advanced too deeply or at an incorrect angle. Accidental puncture of the subclavian artery can lead to complications such as hematoma, hemothorax, and can also be problematic if not recognized because threading a catheter into the arterial system can have catastrophic consequences.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use has developed confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for this presentation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B1

 

The patient's presentation of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, along with a history of chronic alcohol use, is indicative of a deficiency in Vitamin B1 (thiamine). This clinical picture is consistent with Wernicke's Encephalopathy, a serious neurological disorder most commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Alcohol use can lead to poor dietary intake and absorption, contributing to thiamine deficiency. Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the triad of mental confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (eye movement abnormalities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Deficiency in Vitamin B2 can lead to symptoms like skin disorders, anemia, and sore throat, but it is not typically associated with the neurological symptoms described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): While Vitamin B6 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms, they are typically peripheral neuropathies or seizures, not the classic triad seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Deficiency in Vitamin C leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, joint pain, and poor wound healing, which are not consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with chronic alcohol use presenting with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, a Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency leading to Wernicke's Encephalopathy should be considered.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: Choose the egg belonging to the following parasite from the column B? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3

 

The above worm is Enterobius vermicularis

 

Adults are short, white, fusiform worms with pointed ends, looking like bits of white thread. The mouth is surrounded by three wing-like curricular expansions (cervical alae), which are transversely striated. as seen in the image provided in the question. The esophagus has a double bulb structure, a feature unique to this worm.

 

 

The egg is colorless and not bile-stained. It floats in saturated salt solution. It has a characteristic shape, being elongated ovoid, flattened on one side and convex on the other (planoconvex), measuring 50-60 μm by 20-30 μm. The eggshell is double-layered and relatively thick, though transparent. The outer albuminous layer makes the eggs stick to each other and to clothing and other objects. The egg contains a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo, which is fully formed, but becomes infectious only 6 hours after being deposited on the skin. Under cool moist conditions, the egg remains viable for about 2 weeks.

 

 

The correctly matched egg for the given parasite - Enterobius vermicularis is 3

 

Other choices:
 

Option A: Egg of Hymenolepsis nana
 

Option B: Egg of Tenia species 
 

Option D: Fertilized egg of ascaris
 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis eggs are elongated ovoid, flattened on one side and convex on the other, with a double-layered, thick, transparent shell and contain a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo.

choices.text: Complete transection of spinal cord
Ipsilateral loss of vibration & touch
Contralateral loss of pain & temperature

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complete transection of spinal cord

 

A complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome. A complete transection would result in loss of all motor and sensory functions below the level of the injury on both sides of the body, which is different from the hemisection seen in Brown-Séquard syndrome.

 

Brown-Séquard syndrome results from a hemisection or partial lesion of the spinal cord, typically affecting one half. This syndrome is characterized by a distinct pattern of neurological deficits due to the disruption of different spinal cord tracts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ipsilateral loss of vibration & touch: This occurs because the posterior columns (dorsal columns) are affected, leading to loss of proprioception, vibration, and fine touch on the same side as the lesion.

 

Option C. Contralateral loss of pain & temperature: This results from the damage to the spinothalamic tract, which crosses to the opposite side of the spinal cord. Therefore, pain and temperature sensations are lost on the side opposite to the lesion.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral loss of proprioception: Like the loss of vibration and touch, proprioception is also affected ipsilaterally due to involvement of the posterior columns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brown-Séquard syndrome is characterized by hemisection of the spinal cord, leading to ipsilateral loss of vibration, touch, and proprioception, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature. Complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of this syndrome

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with a history of rapidly enlarging swelling in her right breast for the last 15 days. During the physical examination, there was a local rise in temperature, and the lump was partially mobile over the chest wall. What could be the probable diagnosis for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammatory carcinoma

 

Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer. It presents with rapid onset of swelling (edema), redness (erythema), and warmth due to its tendency to block the lymphatic vessels in the skin of the breast. This blockage leads to the classic "peau d'orange" appearance, resembling the skin of an orange. A local rise in temperature and rapid progression of symptoms (as in 15 days) can be consistent with inflammatory carcinoma. The tumor might be mobile initially, but as the disease progresses, it becomes fixed. Given the described symptoms and rapid onset, inflammatory carcinoma is a probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Giant fibroadenoma: Fibroadenomas are benign tumors composed of glandular and connective tissue. They are usually painless, mobile, and have a rubbery consistency. While they don't typically present with inflammation or a rapid onset of symptoms, giant fibroadenomas are larger than typical fibroadenomas (>5cm). They are seen in the 15 to 25 year old age group.

 

Option C. Phyllodes tumor: Phyllodes tumors are rare breast tumors that can be benign, borderline, or malignant. They can grow quickly and become quite large, and while they might be mobile, they do not typically present with inflammatory signs like warmth or redness.

 

Option D. Galactocele: A galactocele is a milk-filled cyst that can form in the breast. It typically presents in women who are lactating or have recently stopped lactating. While a galactocele can cause a lump in the breast, it doesn't cause inflammatory symptoms such as a local rise in temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given scenario, the patient's rapid onset of disease and examination findings suggest inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, which is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer.
  • Inflammatory breast cancer typically presents with brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (Peau d'orange appearance), along with a breast lump.
  • Skin biopsy is used to diagnose inflammatory breast cancer.
  • The treatment for inflammatory breast cancer includes combined-modality treatment, such as neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy for ER-positive tumors, and Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis with tubo-ovarian mass

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is the most likely diagnosis in view of the following points
    • Age
    • Symptoms: low grade fever, weight loss, pain and amenorrhoea
    • Adnexal mass with ascites

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian malignancy: Ovarian malignancy may present with weight loss, ascites and a pelvic mass. But a young age and amenorrhea do not go in favor of ovarian malignancy

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: Ectopic pregnancy will be an acute presentation and will not present with fever/ weight loss

 

Option D. Submucous fibroid: Submucous fibroid presents with menorrhagia/ inter-menstrual bleeding and the uterus will be uniformly enlarged. There will not be any pelvic mass. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis with a tubo-ovarian mass is suspected in young patients presenting with low-grade fever, weight loss, amenorrhea, and a pelvic mass with signs of ascites.

 

Ref: Page no 141, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: From the options given below, which of these does not belong to the category of cardiac poison?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Atropa belladonna  

 

Atropa belladonna is not considered a cardiac poison. It is known for its anticholinergic properties and is part of the Solanaceae family, which includes Datura stramonium and Hyoscyamus niger. The active principles in these plants include atropine, hyoscine (scopolamine), and hyoscyamine, which exhibit anticholinergic effects.

 

Atropa Belladona

 

  • Solanaceae family: Datura stramonium, Atropa belladonna (deadly nightshade) and Hyoscyamus niger (henbane) all belong to same family Solanaceae

  • Anticholinergic alkaloids: All of these plants have similar alkaloids, and all of these alkaloids have anticholinergic properties.

  • Active Principles: Examples of important active principles found in these alkaloids are Atropine, Hyoscine (scopolamine), Hyoscyamine.

  • Align and symptoms: All of these have similar anticholinergic sign and symptoms, especially delirium.

  • Atropa Belladona have black berries as shown below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aconite: Aconite is a cardiac poison. It affects the heart by causing arrhythmias and other cardiac disturbances.

 

Option B. Cerbera thevetia: Cerbera thevetia, also known as yellow oleander, is a well-known cardiac poison. It contains cardiac glycosides that affect the heart's rhythm and contractility.

 

Option C. Nicotiana tabacum: Nicotiana tabacum, or tobacco, contains nicotine, which has significant effects on the cardiovascular system, including causing hypertension and tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac Poisons (Mnemonic: DHONAQ)

  • Digitalis Purpurea (Digitalis)

  • HCN

  • Oleander (Kaner): 

         > White Oleander (Nerium Odorum)

         > Yellow Oleander (Cerebra Thevetia)

  • Nicotiana Tobaccum (Nicotine, Tobacco)

  • Aconite (Monk’s Hood, Mitha Zaher)

  • Quinine (Cinchona Plant)

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their action at shoulder joint: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

A. Latissimus dorsi: This muscle is known as the "stand at ease" muscle, the "climbers muscle," and the "swimmers muscle." It originates from the back and inserts into the front between two major muscles. When it contracts, it causes backward movement, extension, adduction, and medial rotation of the shoulder. Therefore, its action is extension with medial rotation (Action 2).

 

B. Supraspinatus: Located above the spine of the scapula, the supraspinatus muscle, when it contracts, moves the arm away from the midline, which is known as abduction. Hence, its action is abduction (Action 3).

 

C. Infraspinatus: This muscle originates from the back and rotates the arm outward when it contracts, causing lateral rotation. Thus, its action is lateral rotation (Action 4).

 

D. Pectoralis Major (sternal head): Originating from the midline (sternum and clavicle) and inserting into the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus, this muscle, when contracted, causes movement to the front (flexion). Therefore, its action is flexion (Action 1).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Latissimus dorsi is responsible for extension with medial rotation.
  • Supraspinatus is responsible for abduction.
  • Infraspinatus is responsible for lateral rotation.
  • Pectoralis Major (sternal head) is responsible for flexion.

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

Autoimmunity refers to immune reactions against self-antigens. Normal persons are unresponsive (tolerant) to their own (self) antigens, and autoimmunity results from a failure of self-tolerance.

 

Self-tolerance involves two broad mechanisms: Central Tolerance and Peripheral Tolerance.

 

AIRE (Autoimmune regulator) stimulates expression of some peripheral tissue-restricted self-antigens in the thymus and is critical for deletion of immature T cells specific for these self-antigens. Mutations in the AIRE gene are the cause of an autoimmune polyendocrinopathy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: NOTCH1 plays a role in cell growth and division (proliferation), maturation (differentiation), and self-destruction (apoptosis).

 

Option B. E2A: E2A proteins function by recruiting proteins that drive epigenetic remodeling that precedes transcription.

 

Option C. Rag ½: Recombination-activating genes RAG 1 and RAG 2 initiate the molecular processes that lead to lymphocyte receptor formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AIRE gene is crucial for promoting self-tolerance by ensuring that developing T cells in the thymus are exposed to self-antigens, thus preventing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: In a given population, total births were 4050 including 50 stillbirths in a given year. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life, and an additional 150 die within 8-28 days of life. What is the Neonatal mortality rate in the population? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50

 

The Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) is a key indicator of neonatal health and is calculated as the number of neonatal deaths per 1000 live births. The neonatal period spans from birth up to 28 days and is further divided into:

 

  • Early Neonatal Period: 0-7 days
  • Late Neonatal Period: 8-28 days

 

Calculation:

 

  • Total births: 4050 (including 50 stillbirths)
  • Neonatal deaths:
    • Early Neonatal Period: 50 deaths
    • Late Neonatal Period: 150 deaths
  • Total Neonatal Deaths: 50 + 150 = 200 deaths
  • Total Live Births: 4050 - 50 (stillbirths) = 4000 live births
  • Neonatal Mortality Rate Formula:

 

 

  • Calculate NMR

 

 

Thus, the Ans.  is 50 per 1000 live births.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) is calculated as the number of neonatal deaths per 1000 live births.
